options.content:
# Topology Overiew

The IBM Cloud Pak for AIOps Topology system is comprised of the following components:
- ***Observers***: Responsible for obtaining near real-time data from resources and feeding it into the AIOps system via Kafka.
- ***Status Service***: Correlates new alerts to their topological resources.
- ***Merge Service***: Handles the merging of resources into composite resources.
It also handles merge rules and group template processing.
- ***Topology Service***: Main topology component that manages the JanusGraph database.
It processes topological objects (vertices) & their relationships (edges) with a number of processes.
- ***Layout Service***: Provides graph layout algorithms for displaying topological data in the UI.
- ***Inventory Service***: Search engine for optimzing topological queries.

**Dependencies:**
- ***JanusGraph***: Highly scalable graph database used for composition and storage of vertices and edges. Uses Cassandra for actual storage.
- ***Cassandra***: Topological database. Topological objects (vertices) and their relationships (edges) are stored here.
- ***Kafka***: Message Broker system for ingesting requests and outputting results.
- ***Postgres***: Search engine database used for optimzing queries.

panels.description:
Count that tracks the number of pods that were newly created within the time range.

New pods indicate restarts may have occurred which could result in loss of functionality. Review the component pod uptime time series to see if any gaps in uptime occurred.

New pods don't always indicate a problem and in some cases are part of routine processing and scaling.

0.text: pods are stable - no new pods within time range

1.text: 1 new pod within time range - review uptime graph for gaps

2.text: 2 new pods within time range - review uptime graph for gaps

3.text: 3 new pods within time range - review uptime graph for gaps

4.text: 4 new pods within time range - review uptime graph for gaps

5.text: 5 new pods within time range - review uptime graph for gaps

6.text: 6 new pods within time range - review uptime graph for gaps

7.text: 7 new pods within time range - review uptime graph for gaps

8.text: 8 new pods within time range - review uptime graph for gaps

9.text: 9 new pods within time range - review uptime graph for gaps

result.text: 10-20 new pods within time range - review uptime graph for gaps
21-40 new pods within time range - review uptime graph for gaps
41+ new pods within time range - review uptime graph for gaps

defaults.noValue: pods are stable - no new pods within time range

targets.expr: sum(((sum((time() - kube_pod_start_time{pod=~".*-topology-.*", pod!~".*cassandra.*", pod!~".*file-observer.*", pod!~".*kubernetes-observer.*", pod!~".*observer.*",pod!~".*api.*", pod!~".*aiopsedge.*", pod!~".*job.*", pod!~".*schema.*"}) - $__range_s) by (pod)) < 60) <= bool 0)

kube_pod_status_phase{pod=~".*-topology-.*", pod!~".*cassandra.*", pod!~".*file-observer.*", pod!~".*kubernetes-observer.*", pod!~".*observer.*",pod!~".*api.*", pod!~".*aiopsedge.*", pod!~".*job.*", pod!~".*schema.*", phase=~"Running|Pending|Unknown"} == 1

time() -sum(kube_pod_start_time{pod=~".*-topology-.*", pod!~".*cassandra.*", pod!~".*file-observer.*", pod!~".*kubernetes-observer.*", pod!~".*observer.*",pod!~".*api.*", pod!~".*aiopsedge.*", pod!~".*job.*", pod!~".*schema.*"}) by (pod)

panels.description:
Count of pods that have exceeded 80% of their CPU limits within the time range. This will result in CPU throttling and potentially temporary loss of functionality

This will only compare against the ***current*** CPU limit of each pod. If the limits were updated within the time range, the count may be inaccurate.

0.text: pod-level CPU usage is stable - all usage has stayed under 80% of current limits

1.text: 1 pod has exceeded 80% of their CPU limits - review CPU graphs for spikes

2.text: 2 pods have exceeded 80% of their CPU limits - review CPU graphs for spikes

3.text: 3 pods have exceeded 80% of their CPU limits - review CPU graphs for spikes

4.text: 4 pods have exceeded 80% of their CPU limits - review CPU graphs for spikes

result.text: 5+ pods have exceeded 80% of their CPU limits - review CPU graphs for spikes

targets.expr: sum((((max(kube_pod_container_resource_limits{pod=~".*-topology-.*", pod!~".*cassandra.*", pod!~".*file-observer.*", pod!~".*kubernetes-observer.*", pod!~".*observer.*",pod!~".*api.*", pod!~".*aiopsedge.*", pod!~".*job.*", pod!~".*schema.*", container!="", container!="POD", resource="cpu"}) by (pod)) * 0.8 <= max(max_over_time(node_namespace_pod_container:container_cpu_usage_seconds_total:sum_irate{pod=~".*-topology-.*", pod!~".*cassandra.*", pod!~".*file-observer.*", pod!~".*kubernetes-observer.*", pod!~".*observer.*",pod!~".*api.*", pod!~".*aiopsedge.*", pod!~".*job.*", pod!~".*schema.*", container!="", container!="POD"}[$__range])) by (pod)) or vector(0)) > bool 0)

panels.description: Total count of messages sent by Topology Observers to the central Topology Service within the time range.
panels.title: Total Observer Traffic (messages)

panels.description: Total number of bytes sent by Topology Observers to the central Topology Service within the time range.
panels.title: Total Observer Traffic (bytes)

panels.description:
Histogram displaying the message processing times of incoming traffic from Topology Observers via Kafka occurring within the time range. 

This gives insight into the volume of messages being fed into Topology by the Observers and how quickly those messages are being processed.

Values on the left are ranges of time in seconds, values on the right are the number of requests that fall into that time range.
panels.title: Topology Observer message processing times (seconds)

panels.description: Count of messages sent by each Topology Observer to the central Topology Service within the time range.
panels.title: Traffic per Observer

This gives insight into the volume of messages being fed into the topology sub-component and how quickly those messages are being processed.

Values on the left are ranges of time in seconds, values on the right are the number of requests that fall into that time range.

panels.title: Processing times (Inventory service)

panels.description:
This time series displays the message processing lag over time per topology sub-component. Message lag is the number of messages that are waiting to be processed. The higher the lag, the longer it will take for new messages to get processed.

Lag will increase during message bursts but should always stabilize and ideally decrease. If lag is steadily increasing over time, more resources may need to be allocated to sub-component to ensure timely message processing.
panels.title: Message Processing Lag

panels.description:
Current message lag per component. Message lag is the number of messages that are waiting to be processed. The higher the lag, the longer it will take for new messages to get processed.

Lag will increase during message bursts but should always stabilize and ideally decrease. If lag is steadily increasing over time, more resources may need to be allocated to sub-component to ensure timely message processing.
panels.title: Message Processing Lag (current)

panels.description:
This time series displays the message processing lag over time for the Topology Service. This is the central component that acts as the point of entry for messages coming in from Topological observers. As such, spikes are expected to occur at each collection interval.

The legend on the right shows: "<topic> - <partition>". Topics act as roads between components, allowing messages to pass from one to the other. Topics are made up of partitions, like lanes in the road.  Messages relating to a particular resource, are typically sent to the same partition to maintain ordering. Too much traffic on one partition is what causes lag.

Lag will increase during message bursts but should always stabilize and ideally decrease. If lag is steadily increasing over time, more resources may need to be allocated to sub-component to ensure timely message processing.
panels.title: Message Processing Lag (Topology Service)

panels.description:
This time series displays the message processing lag over time for the Inventory Service.

The legend on the right shows: "<topic> - <partition>". Topics act as roads between components, allowing messages to pass from one to the other. Topics are made up of partitions, like lanes in the road.  Messages relating to a particular resource, are typically sent to the same partition to maintain ordering. Too much traffic on one partition is what causes lag.

Lag will increase during message bursts but should always stabilize and ideally decrease. If lag is steadily increasing over time, more resources may need to be allocated to sub-component to ensure timely message processing.
panels.title: Message Processing Lag (Inventory Service)

The legend on the right shows: "<topic> - <partition>". Topics act as roads between components, allowing messages to pass from one to the other. Too much traffic on one partition is what causes lag.

Lag will increase during message bursts but should always stabilize and ideally decrease. If lag is steadily increasing over time, more resources may need to be allocated to sub-component to ensure timely message processing.
panels.title: Message Processing Lag (Status Service)

panels.description:
This time series displays the message processing lag over time for the Merge Service.

The legend on the right shows: "<topic> - <partition>". Topics act as roads between components, allowing messages to pass from one to the other. Topics are made up of partitions, like lanes in the road.  Messages relating to a particular resource, are typically sent to the same partition to maintain ordering. Too much traffic on one partition is what causes lag.

Lag will increase during message bursts but should always stabilize and ideally decrease. If lag is steadily increasing over time, more resources may need to be allocated to sub-component to ensure timely message processing.
panels.title: Message Processing Lag (Merge Service)

panels.description: Count of database queries executed by the Topology Service within the time range
panels.title: Database queries

panels.description:
Timeline of Topology database request times, made by the Topology Service, represented in quantiles.

A quantile represents a percentage of the requests. Quantiles are computed across 10 minute sliding windows.

***p50=1s*** means 50% of all requests in the window took less than or equal to 1s

***p98=3s*** means 98% of all requests in the window took less than or equal to 3s

***p99.9=5s*** means 99.9% of all requests in the window took less than or equal to 5s
panels.title: Database request time quantiles

panels.description: Count of database query failures made by the Topology Service within the time range

defaults.noValue: All queries successful within time range

panels.title: Database query failures
